column5: I forgot my taste for Suckers,Yum!!!!!
There is only walleye.

It's been a long time since I've had a stuffed baked whitefish.Dad had a commercial fishing licence so it was a regular meal back then.I do miss that. Need to figure out how to catch whitefish on LOTW!
My vote is for Walleye, then Bluegill, followed by Perch with Northern being up there too
Straight walleye cheeks. Eat them by the pounds. Had a 5 gallon pail full after commercial fishing last winter, mmmmm
The best tasting fresh water fish, in that order, walleye,perch,pike,crappie. The best eating fresh water fish has to be pike they eat alot. Is this a trick ?

A fresh Halibut fillet with a light breading and some creole seasoning in a between a couple of pieces of fresh bread with a little good Tartar sauce or Mayo. OMG delicious. And Walleye Tacos with a Chipotle sour cream and good cabbage and onions one of my all time favorite.
For me it's either a deep fried fresh perch, northern or walleye. I don't have a preference between the three. Next would be a pan fried rainbow trout.
A fresh lake trout out of 40 Degree water grilled with special sauce.Paul
Smelt, seine caught in lake Superior, like lays potato chips you simply cannot have just one...Next up would be smaller channel cats early in the season, sweet, light flaky meat nummy...
My vote is fresh walleye coated in buttermilk pancake flour with salt/pepper cooked in butter on an open fire. Let the fire burn down first so you don't burn the butter.
-crappie-yellow perch-walleye-spotted bassin no order

Hello: Hey Joeman79 where do you catch those freshwater halibut ? Just kidding. I haven't heard anyone say Yellow Bass caught fresh and deep fried with your favorite fish mix. Good Luck everybody this season. O - R
I did not read freshwater I guess, i was speed readin. My bad sorry. Walleye is my favorite. What is a Yellow Bass???? New one to me.
freshly caught bluegill - from the fillet table to the deep fryer - with an ice cold micro brew.

This comes down to about maybe a half dozen to a dozen fresh water species from North America at most that people on these forums have tried. Who knows what might be tastier on other continents? For me, I like them all except for sucker (yes, I tried it once). But there's just something about lightly breaded fresh yellow perch. Among all fish, it's hard to beat halibut.

I'm with you, Bob. Unlike many other species, bigger crappies are (in my opinion) much better than the smaller ones. Those large LOW crappies just flake the layers apart when fried up, completely different texture than small ones. Bill Krejca
Now that I think some more about it (not difficult, yum), lake trout on the grill on foil, seasoned with Hy-Vee made meat seasoning is also hard to beat. Bill

RMTHOMPSON...you are right...find someone who can show you how to fillet a pike properly...hard to beat...but a combination of pike and walleye cooked over an open fire, fries, onions and ice cold beer ...(not telling how it got there but in spring walleye waters can be just cold enough)...oh I can wait until Saturday for the first shore lunch of the week!

Kokanee from a large cold lake in British Columbia. They are quite small so you need to catch quite a few for a meal, but as for taste, what else would you expect from a landlocked Sockeye Salmon? Yummy!!!!! My second favourite would be some fillets from a Laker in the 4-6 pound range.
Nothing like fresh blackened lake trout. Unless its walleye about 15 in, battered in Andy's and fried in peanut oil, pared with a cold beer and a Cuban cigar!!
The best I have had1. Smoked Trout by the natives2. Perch3. Walleye

Fresh walleye layer with Rocky Madsens Fish Crisp and deep fried in peanut oil. That very first meal when you get to camp is to die for. I always eat too much! Otherwise perch is a good second and northern 3rd if you get the Y bones out. Lately I've been grilling my fish and that has also been very good.

Lotta people here (old timers) swear pike are the best,others say Cat fish and I say .......Walleye by far is the best but I did cook a Stealhead once that was awesome as well!!! Other than that I stick to Haddock or Talapia if my freezer is outta walleye fillets.....
By the way I have also cooked up some good tasting smallies as well,if im desperate/crave fresh fish.....

A 26 inch northern, fresh, not frozen. Filleted. Cut into 3"-4" long pieces. One pass thru milk/egg bath, then corn flake crumbs. Drop the skinny pieces into the oil a minute earlier than the thicker pieces and everything in the fryer is done at the same time. We dump the fried fish onto a cookie sheet covered with a paper grocery bag to drain the oil and put it in the pre-heated oven until everything is ready to eat. Remove the Y-bones when you filet the fish if you know how. If you don't, you can remove them after the filets are cooked. Just break the cooked filet in half, parallel to the lateral line. With a little practice, all the Y-bones pop up for easy removal. Rick

I think the best fresh water fish species to eat in Canada are; 1. Perch 2. Walleye 3. Crappie 4. Pike (deboned) 5. Brook Trout from a creek. If I catch a Bluegill or a Sunfish it goes back! Not worth the bother to clean. The Lake I fish has "Magnum" size Perch which are consistly up around 13 - 15" where I can get big filets off of them. I caught one 2yrs ago that was just over 2lbs!! There is a Lake 3hrs from my house that has Perch consistently just over 2lbs and a couple have been 2 1/2 lbs from what I heard. The main fish up there is "Walleye" and they think Bluegills, Crappie, Perch are garbage fish and no one fishes them. I was told by a professional angler who is a guide in that area that he know of only 2 guys who fish it specially for Perch. I hope to try the Lake out this year.

" I was told by a professional angler who is a guide in that area that he know of only 2 guys who fish it specially for Perch. I hope to try the Lake out this year. "OK, what is the name and where is it?
last time on Lac Seul we made a medley of pike, perch, sauger, walleye cut into smallish peices and deep fried. that doesn't answer your survey but man that meal sticks out in the memory banks.
X2 Shore lunch is very hard to beat!!!!

With no doubt hard to argue with most of the picks, but fry anything and it will taste good, but always taste better on some rock in the middle of the lake with a can of beans and potatoesAnd by no means I will say this is better but I crave a decent sized trout ( rainbow , brown or laker ) cut into steaks , seasoned and let the BBQ do the rest.Or our clasic x-mas eve diner. A nice 6 - 8 pound laker. Stuff it with wild rice and other goodies, put on the foil and then BBQ.In the middle of winter out at the cottage after a full day of fishing. At that very time hard to beat pike chowder. A couple of bowls of that and good night Irean.How about this ...Sunday afternoon at home in front of your fav football game with smoked trout and deer jurky and a nice cold beer.

Get all that ice cold beer to the shore lunch? OPP would like to know! This is Walleye Central, I have to go Wally's first, because the filet is meatier, perch, then northern pike. I do like that medley of fried W,P, and Northerns. The perch in Minaki have had a worm problem for years. Have really missed eating the perch.
A native rainbow trout - pan fried, little butter literally will melt in the mouth. Don't get me started on stockies...
1. Walleye2. Perch3. NorthernAnd I don't how it is cooked; fried, grilled, or baked. Yum
I guess I've been eating too many perch and walleye. Fresh caught smelt are my favorite. Fried just for a minute. Moist and flaky, and yummy. Labatt to wash em down. emm emm.
Not that many voted for Bluegill's?#1-Gill's/Perch (It's a tie,both **** good)beer battered#2-Walleye beer battered of coarse
Cajun shore lunch walleye with an endless amount of ice cold bottled beer!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Yes, Northern are excellent. I've recently been getting good at the y bone thing. They're excellent.Trout
Bullheads caught through the ice and blackened in the shanty. YUMMY!
I've had many-many years to try a lot of differant fish, and my vote is for pan fried channel cat.
You catch um--I'll cook um.........
Nuthin' sweeter than a good Lake of the Woods Crappie. Then Perch, then walleye.
Fresh Perch, caught through the ice.... nothin' compares!
It's funny how this thread pops up about once every 3 months. There is one that stands above all the rest...perch.

Some may find this strange.I prefer Northern really. I know how to remove the bones and that is the main point right their. Once they are gone you have the tastiest piece of fish you will ever find.Sure they are slimmy, and might even smell a bit. This is not in the flesh itself.Just find someone to show you how to remove those Y bones and see what I mean..Ron
1. carp under 18" deep fried2. walleye fried3. baked catfish
Great eating....I prefer them baked to fried...

Dont forget to tenderize that carp by leaving it on the road for a good three days, so the tires get the meat nice and tender... If it has just snowed, the road salt will preserve the fish, so no need for cooking.<{{}}><
Don't see tire chains much anymore. They were really good for tenderizing a prime cut of meat.

Hey AllI like fresh walleye coated in cornflakes crumbs or cheeses crumbs.....they make the best batter going....but on the shore I like just butter , fish ,pepper a dash of salt ....a fork if I am trying to act civil lolGood fishing and hunting. pass it on ...take a youngsterGood fishing and hunting. pass it on ...take a youngster
Joe, that discription has my mouth watering. I've never had whitefish anything but smoked. Any possibility that you could do a couple for our WC get together?
Except fresh crappies fillets pulled ice fishing! I will agree that perch are pretty tough to beat though.
Humble opinion as to top 5 from this fat guy (me):#1 Perch#2 small walleyes (under 18")#3 larger walleye in small chunks#4 crappie#5 Northern
In order:1: Sauger2: Sunfish3: Perch4: WalleyeEverything else including Crappie and Channel Cats goes back in the river.
Boneless northern pike, beer battered and deep fried is hard to beat.
Can't beat a musky over 50 inches, or a wally over 30 inches!!!Just thought I should stir the fire a bit.
Walleye, Crappie, Perch, White Bass and Blue Gills are hard to beat. To my liking, a channel catfish is the best. Small ones that is. Nothing over about 1 1/2 pound. Hows 'bout yous guys?

A baked whitefish on the grill. Gut and gill it, leave the head on and put some season salt and garlic powder on the inside. Wrap it in tin foil, and put on the grill for about 20 minutes. The fish is best when served with melted butter.........sweet!!!!!!
Channel cats(18" to 22") and perch, then walleye(19" or less).Ed "Backwater Eddy" Carlson...><sUMo>Backwater Guiding"Ed on the RED"
1. Walleye-shore lunch on a northern lake.2. Crappie and bluegill caught through the ice.
I like to take a big fat Illinois carp and stuff him with road kill and then bake him for 1 hour at 350 and smother him with cajun hot sauce....and dig in.
Inquiring minds want to know Barney, what kind of road kill?
Nothing.... absolutely nothing, beats fresh perch.
Sunfish, scaled, filleted, leave the skin on, and fried, WOW
Approx 24 inch pike. It's amazing if you can deal with the Y bones. Anyone else like pike?
A 4lb. Northern is hard to beat. Especially if you get the Y bones out.
